title: Eyewear entrepreneur puts Australia in the frame
text:
Philippa Coates AFR Magazine deputy editor Aug 23, 2019 — 10.06am Share

Larry Leight is founder of Oliver Peoples and Mr Leight eyewear. He is aged 68 and lives in Santa Monica, California.

You grew up in Santa Monica in the 1960s, which was surely a golden era in surfing.

From starting high school in 1965, when we stored our boards in a locker under what is now known as Santa Monica pier, I was instantly drawn to the lifestyle. Between 1967 and 1969 I surfed the California coast and in 1970 I went to Honolua Bay on Maui and that was the first time I surfed a perfect tropical paradise wave. It changed my life. I spent my summer surfing in Lahaina, the same time Jimi Hendrix was filming Rainbow Bridge in Makawao. I bought a house on Kauai near my favourite surf spots and try to visit a couple months each year. Other than Hawaii, I’ve been often to Puerto Rico and Costa Rica.

How does surfing make you feel?

It really is the ultimate escape. Being in the water with all the elements – the sun, the open water, and most of all, the unknown of how the waves would be from day to day – always felt like a Christmas morning. It was considered a new gift each day because back then, we didn’t have a surf forecast to check and we had to guess the conditions based on the wind and weather. We would go and hope for the best. That element of surprise was what inspired us to go as often as possible.

Have you been to Australia?

Only to Sydney for three days and I didn’t get to surf. It was a dream of mine since I was a teenager to spend a few months travelling the Gold Coast to surf and camp but sadly it never materialised.

Leight says eyewear should be like shoes – you wouldn't wear the same pair all the time. Shaughn and John

Are you a nicer person if you've had your surfing fix?

I definitely feel much calmer and I think I approach the day with a more positive attitude. Out on the water is one of the very few places I feel truly at peace; it always allows my mind to be in a creative space. Unfortunately, I’ve struggled in recent years with back issues. It's actually mental torture for me not to be able to get out there more often.

Big board collection? Natural or goofy footer?

I am a goofy footer. I think my first board was a 9’6 Dewey Weber. Since then my collection has grown a little and now I have a range from 9’ to 7’6”.

Favourite time to surf?

It used to be 5am, but now I prefer from 1pm to 4pm or at sunset in Hawaii. Surfing in the middle of the day is special; it feels almost decadent.

Are crowds a turn-off?

Everybody would say crowds are a turn-off. What I have noticed is that the number of people surfing has really jumped in the past five to 10 years.
description: For AFR Magazine's monthly Other Passions column about the hobbies of successful people, we speak to Mr Leight eyewear company founder Larry Leight about his love of surfing in Hawaii and California.
